thread.title: "Star Wars" fans crash websites, line up for tickets for "The Force Awakens"
thread.title_full: "Star Wars" fans crash websites, line up for tickets for "The Force Awakens" - CBS News

author: Lauren Moraski CBS News
title: "Star Wars" fans crash websites, line up for tickets for "The Force Awakens"
text:
"Star Wars" fans came out in droves on Monday to snag tickets to "The Force Awakens," crashing websites and even standing in old-fashioned lines.
36 Photos Meet the cast of "Star Wars: Episode VII" Check out the new faces and returning favorites from J.J. Abrams' "The Force Awakens"
The trailer for the upcoming installment debuted during "Monday Night Football " as sites put tickets up for sale -- even earlier than expected . Needles to say, they are in demand.
Ticket sites were slow and there were reports of sites crashing, not able to keep up with the demand. Fandango, AMC Theaters and the Alamo Drafthouse were among the sites facing issues.
Ticket retailer site MovieTickets.com also went down on Monday night. "That's what happens when a nation unites to buy tix for one movie on the same night!" MovieTickets.com tweeted.
@frankpallotta that's what happens when a nation unites to buy tix for one movie on the same night! #TheForceAwakens
— MovieTickets.com (@MovieTickets) October 20, 2015 Other movie lovers headed to the theater to wait in line to purchase their tickets.
Old school line at @alamodenver Thanks for being there when most of the Internet was denying my #starwars tix. pic.twitter.com/XtpfdZ19lp
— John Hamilton (@johnhamilton) October 20, 2015 Hundreds of people, meanwhile, gathered in downtown Disney to watch the entire trailer, while others waited in anticipation to watch from home.
"Star Wars: The Force Awakens" doesn't even open in theaters until Dec. 18. Until then, may the force be with you.
